paris-parc-des-princes.title: Paris, Parc des Princes
paris-parc-des-princes.description: The Parc des Princes is an all-seater football stadium located in the southwest of Paris, France. The venue, with a seating capacity of 48,712 spectators, has been the home of French football club Paris Saint-Germain since 1973. Named after the Monarch's hunting grounds that it sits on, it was initially opened as a multi-purpose venue on 18 July 1897

paris-the-eiffel-tower.title: Paris, the Eiffel Tower
paris-the-eiffel-tower.description: The Eiffel Tower is a wrought iron lattice tower on the Champ de Mars in Paris, France. It is named after the engineer Gustave Eiffel, whose company designed and built the tower.Constructed in 1889 as the entrance to the 1889 World's Fair, it has become a global cultural icon of France and one of the most recognisable structures in the world

paris-the-river-seine.title: Paris, the river Seine
paris-the-river-seine.description: The Seine is a 777-kilometre (483 mi) long river and an important commercial waterway within the Paris Basin in the north of France.There are 37 bridges within Paris and dozens more spanning the river outside the city.

paris-montmartre-and-sacre-coeur.title: Paris, Montmartre and Sacre-Coeur
paris-montmartre-and-sacre-coeur.description: Montmartre is a large hill in Paris's 18th arrondissement. It is 130 metres high and gives its name to the surrounding district, part of the Right Bank in the northern section of the city. At the beginning of the twentieth century, during the Belle Époque, many artists had studios or worked in or around Montmartre, including Salvador Dalí, Amedeo Modigliani, Claude Monet, Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec, Piet Mondrian, Pablo Picasso, Camille Pissarro and Vincent van Gogh. Montmartre is also the setting for several hit films.

paris-luxembourg-gardens-and-the-senate.title: Paris, Luxembourg Gardens and the Senate
paris-luxembourg-gardens-and-the-senate.description: The Luxembourg Palace was originally built to be the royal residence of the regent Marie de Médicis, mother of Louis XIII of France. Since 1958 it has been the seat of the French Senate of the Fifth Republic.On the south side of the palace, the formal Luxembourg Garden presents a 25-hectare green parterre of gravel and lawn populated with statues and large basins of water where children sail model boats.

paris-cathedral-notre-dame-de-paris.title: Paris, Cathedral Notre-Dame de Paris
paris-cathedral-notre-dame-de-paris.description: Notre-Dame de Paris is a medieval Catholic cathedral on the eastern half of the Île de la Cité. The cathedral is widely considered to be one of the finest examples of French Gothic architecture, and it is among the largest and most well-known church buildings in the world. The naturalism of its sculptures and stained glass are in contrast with earlier Romanesque architecture.

paris-hotel-de-ville.title: Paris, Hôtel de Ville
paris-hotel-de-ville.description: The Hôtel de Ville in Paris, France, is the building housing the city's local administration. Standing on the place de l'Hôtel-de-Ville in the 4th arrondissement, it has been the headquarters of the municipality of Paris since 1357. It serves multiple functions, housing the local administration, the Mayor of Paris (since 1977), and also serves as a venue for large receptions.

paris-palais-garnier.title: Paris, Palais Garnier
paris-palais-garnier.description: The Palais Garnie is a 1,979-seat opera house, which was built from 1861 to 1875 for the Paris Opera. The Palais Garnier has been called "probably the most famous opera house in the world, a symbol of Paris like Notre Dame Cathedral, the Louvre, or the Sacré Coeur Basilica." This is at least partly due to its use as the setting for Gaston Leroux's 1910 novel The Phantom of the Opera..

paris-gare-du-nord.title: Paris, Gare du Nord
paris-gare-du-nord.description: Paris Nord is one of the six large terminus stations of the SNCF mainline network for Paris, France. The Gare du Nord offers connections with several urban transport lines, including Paris Métro, RER and Buses. By the number of travellers, at around 190 million per year, it is the busiest railway station in Europe and the busiest in the world outside Japan.

marseille-nouveau-stade-velodrome.title: Marseille, Nouveau Stade Vélodrome
marseille-nouveau-stade-velodrome.description: The Stade Vélodrome is a multi-purpose stadium in Marseille, France. It is home to the Olympique de Marseille football club of Ligue 1 since it opened in 1937, and was a venue in the 1998 FIFA World Cup and the 2007 Rugby World Cup. The stadium is also used regularly by the French rugby union team.

marseille-port-marseille-ajaccio-and-sho.title: Marseille, Port Marseille-Ajaccio and shopping mall Terrasses du port

marseille-area-calanques-national-park.title: Marseille area, Calanques National Park
marseille-area-calanques-national-park.description: Calanques National Park is a national park located in southern France, established in 2012. It includes parts of the Massif des Calanques stretching between Marseille and Cassis.

marseille-gare-marseille-saint-charles.title: Marseille, Gare Marseille Saint Charles
marseille-gare-marseille-saint-charles.description: Marseille – Saint-Charles is the main railway station and intercity bus station of Marseille. The station is currently the 11th busiest in France.

nice-allianz-riviera.title: Nice, Allianz Riviera
nice-allianz-riviera.description: The Allianz Riviera is a multi-use stadium in Nice, France, used mostly for football matches of host OGC Nice and also for occasional home matches of rugby union club Toulon.

nice-promenade-des-anglais.title: Nice, Promenade des Anglais
nice-promenade-des-anglais.description: The Promenade des Anglais is a celebrated promenade along the Mediterranean at Nice, France.

nice-gare-de-nice-ville.title: Nice, Gare de Nice-Ville
nice-gare-de-nice-ville.description: Nice-Ville (French: Gare de Nice-Ville) is the main railway station in Nice, France.

lyon-parc-olympique-lyonnais.title: Lyon, Parc Olympique Lyonnais
lyon-parc-olympique-lyonnais.description: The Parc Olympique Lyonnais, nicknamed the Grand Stade and the Stade des Lumières, is a 59,186-seat stadium for French football club Olympique Lyonnais in Décines near Lyon. It replaced its previous stadium, Stade de Gerland, in January 2016.It is a scheduled venue for UEFA Euro 2016 and the 2019 FIFA Women's World Cup.

lyon-basilica-of-notre-dame-de-fourviere.title: Lyon, Basilica of Notre-Dame de Fourvière
lyon-basilica-of-notre-dame-de-fourviere.description: The Basilica of Notre-Dame de Fourvière is a minor basilica in Lyon. It was built with private funds between 1872 and 1884 in a dominant position overlooking the city.

lyon-parc-de-la-tete-dor.title: Lyon, Parc de la Tête d'Or
lyon-parc-de-la-tete-dor.description: Parc de la Tête d'Or ("Park of the Golden Head"), in Lyon, is a large urban park in Franc. It features a lake on which boating takes place during the summer months. Due to the relatively small number of other parks in Lyon, it receives a huge number of visitors over summer, and is a frequent destination for joggers and cyclists. In the central part of the park, there is a small zoo, with giraffes, elephants, deer, reptiles, primates, and other animals.

lyon-gare-de-lyon-part-dieu.title: Lyon, Gare de Lyon-Part-Dieu
lyon-gare-de-lyon-part-dieu.description: Gare de la Part-Dieu is the primary railway station in Lyon, Rhône-Alpes in south-east France, European Union. It is situated on the Paris-Lyon-Marseille railway.

toulouse-stade-municipal-de-toulouse.title: Toulouse, Stade Municipal de Toulouse
toulouse-stade-municipal-de-toulouse.description: Stadium Municipal de Toulouse is the largest multi-purpose stadium in Toulouse, France. It is currently used mostly for football matches, mainly those of the Toulouse Football Club and the big games of rugby for Stade Toulousain in the European Rugby Champions Cup or Top 14. The stadium is able to hold 33,150 people

toulouse-cite-de-lespace.title: Toulouse, Cite de l'espace
toulouse-cite-de-lespace.description: The Cité de l'espace (City of Space) is a theme park focused on space and the conquest of space. It was opened in September 1997 and is located on the eastern outskirts of Toulouse, France. As of 2012, there had been more than 4 million visitors.

toulouse-gare-toulouse-matabiau.title: Toulouse, Gare Toulouse Matabiau
toulouse-gare-toulouse-matabiau.description: Toulouse-Matabiau is the main railway station in Toulouse, southern France. It is located in the city centre and connected to the Toulouse Metro.

lille-stade-pierre-mauroy.title: Lille, Stade Pierre Mauroy
lille-stade-pierre-mauroy.description: Stade Pierre-Mauroy is a multi-use stadium in Villeneuve d'Ascq, near Lille, France, that opened in August 2012. It is the new home stadium of LOSC Lille Métropole.

lille-notre-dame-de-la-treille.title: Lille, Notre Dame de la Treille
lille-notre-dame-de-la-treille.description: Lille Cathedral, the Basilica of Notre Dame de la Treille, is a Roman Catholic cathedral and basilica, and a national monument of France, located in the city of Lille.

lille-palais-des-beaux-arts.title: Lille, Palais des Beaux-Arts
lille-palais-des-beaux-arts.description: The Palais des Beaux-Arts de Lille (Lille Palace of Fine Arts) is a municipal museum dedicated to fine arts, modern art, and antiquities. It is one of the largest art museums in France.

lille-gare-de-lille-europe.title: Lille, Gare de Lille Europe
lille-gare-de-lille-europe.description: Lille Europe is a railway station in Lille, Nord-Pas-de-Calais-Picardie, France, European Union.

saint-etienne-stade-geoffroy-guichard.title: Saint-Etienne, Stade Geoffroy-Guichard
saint-etienne-stade-geoffroy-guichard.description: Stade Geoffroy-Guichard is a multi-purpose stadium in Saint-Étienne, France. It is used primarily for football matches, and tournaments such as the 1984 European Football Championship, the Football World Cup 1998 and the Confederations Cup 2003. It is nicknamed "le Chaudron" (the Cauldron), or "l'enfer vert" (the Green Hell), an allusion to the colours worn by the local football team, AS Saint-Étienne

saint-etienne-gare-de-saint-etienne-chat.title: Saint-Étienne, Gare de Saint-Étienne-Châteaucreux
saint-etienne-gare-de-saint-etienne-chat.description: The Gare de Saint-Étienne-Châteaucreux is the main railway station in the town of Saint-Étienne. The station is situated in Châteaucreux, a little outside the centre of Saint-Étienne.

saint-denis-stade-de-france.title: Saint-Denis, Stade de France
saint-denis-stade-de-france.description: The Stade de France is the national stadium of France, situated just north of Paris in the commune of Saint-Denis. Its seating capacity of 81,338 makes it the fifth-largest stadium in Europe. The stadium is used by both the France national football team and French rugby union team for international competition.

saint-denis-the-basilica-of-saint-denis.title: Saint-Denis, the Basilica of Saint Denis
saint-denis-the-basilica-of-saint-denis.description: The Basilica of Saint Denis is a large medieval abbey church in the city of Saint-Denis, now a northern suburb of Paris. The building is of unique importance historically and architecturally as its choir, completed in 1144, is considered to be the first Gothic church.

stade-de-france-saint-denis-station-sain.title: Stade de France – Saint-Denis Station, Saint-Denis
stade-de-france-saint-denis-station-sain.description: Stade de France – Saint-Denis is a railway station serving Saint-Denis, a northern suburb of Paris in Seine-Saint-Denis department, France. It is situated near the Stade de France, on the RER D suburban railway line.

lens-gare-de-lens.title: Lens, Gare de Lens
lens-gare-de-lens.description: Lens railway station is a railway station in Lens, Pas-de-Calais, France. The building was built in 1926-1927 to resemble a steam locomotive with a 23 metre high tower as the chimney. The architect was Urbain Cassan. In December 1984 it was listed as a French National Heritage Site.

lens-city-centre-with-eglise-saint-leger.title: Lens, City centre with Eglise Saint-Leger
lens-city-centre-with-eglise-saint-leger.description: Lens is a commune in the Pas-de-Calais department in northern France. It is one of France's large Picarde cities along with Lille, Valenciennes, Amiens, Roubaix, Tourcoing, Arras, and Douai. The inhabitants are called Lensois.

bordeaux-bordeaux-cathedral.title: Bordeaux, Bordeaux Cathedral
bordeaux-bordeaux-cathedral.description: Bordeaux Cathedral (Cathédrale Saint-André de Bordeaux) is a Roman Catholic cathedral, seat of the Archbishop of Bordeaux-Bazas, located in Bordeaux.

bordeaux-parc-du-chateau-pape-clement.title: Bordeaux, Parc du Château Pape Clément

bordeaux-musee-daquitaine-de-bordeaux.title: Bordeaux, Musée d'Aquitaine de Bordeaux
bordeaux-musee-daquitaine-de-bordeaux.description: The Museum of Aquitaine is a collection of objects and documents from the history of Bordeaux and Aquitane.

bordeaux-gare-de-bordeaux-saint-jean.title: Bordeaux, Gare de Bordeaux-Saint-Jean
bordeaux-gare-de-bordeaux-saint-jean.description: Bordeaux-Saint-Jean or Bordeaux-Midi is the main railway station in the French city of Bordeaux.

parent.title: Eurocup 2016 Highlights
parent.description: Visit the French stadiums where fans can watch their favorite teams compete in the Eurocup 2016 and discover the nearby attractions.
